p.s: The newspaper article Language learning in the UK: can't, won't, don't, written by John Worne and published on the 27th of January in 2015 at The Telegraph deals with the learning of foreign languages in the UK and the authors personal view likewise what he thinks works good what bad.
The article is from a formal paper in this case from The Telegraph.
It is Addressedaddressed to the readers of this paper and Worne wrote it to inform them about the situation and to share his own opinion.
The content of the artucle is the loss of learning and useingusing foreign languages.
Besides the fact that there are fewer people studying foreign languages, the number of A-Level exams and GCSE went down or atleastat least the uptake stalled.
This development is not good for the UK because foreign language skills are essential for the UK's properity and global standing and also necessary in the UK's businesses.
Especially because of their fast-growing markets.

Furthermore language skills can be really helpful at the job market which means that fore emploers it is more interessant or atrractive if you have a combination of a subject with a language thenthan just of of these.

To support the learning of languages there are already some primary schools that start teaching languages and some universitysuniversities are giving their students a chance to study a language alongside another degree subject.
The authors intention is to inform the readers and to show his own opinion.
He writes subjective because he wants to make his opinion clear.
To convince the reader of his opinion WornWorne makes use of some persuasive techniques.
He makes use of inclusive language for example in line 1 our national view or we as parents(line 33), to include the reader into his article (line 34, 35).
With this strategiestrategy the reader feels closer to the author and automaticlyautomatically thinks more or deeper about what he said.
He also uses studysstudies and examples based on facts to underline his arguments and to make it more authenticyauthentic.
The article is structured in 11 parts.
Every part is between one and a few sentences and mostly gives one argument or underlines the argument before.
The first part is from line 1 to line 2.
The second is from line three to line five.
The third one is from line nine to line 10.
From line 12 to line 15 is the fourth part and from line 16 to line 18 the fifth.
The sixth part goes from line 19 to line 23.
The seventh part goes from line 24 to line 26, followed by the eigtheighth part from line 27 to line 29.
Next is the 10 part from line 30 to line 31 and the last part goes from line 32 to line 35.
John WornJohn Worne uses formal and educated language for his article.
He writes long but still clear sentences so that they are easy enough for the reader to understand.
WornWorne also makes use of some stylistic devices.
He starts his article with Can't, won't, don't (l. 1) which is a list.
In this case it is to make the reader curious about the article.
He makes use of another listing in line 17: our trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security to show the reader how important languages are and to give some examples.
He also uses an alliteration Language learning (l. 16) to really get the readers focus on this aspect.
he uses another alliteration Skills survey showed (l. 16) again to get the whole focus of the reader on this point.
In the titeltitle he uses the same alliteration as in line 16: Language learning, like this the reader already knows what the artucle is about.

In Worn'sWorne's article the first sentence and also the first paragraph, which is Can't, won't, don't, three words which sum up out national view on speaking foreign languages (l. 1-2), is very important, because it catches the readers atentionattention and based on the first lines the reader decides to either keep on reading or not to do so.
All in all once can say WornWorne is in the opinion that the UK should give more support on learning foreign languages because languages are really important nowdaysnowadays.
To convince his readers he makes use of stylistic devices and also some peruasive techniques.
So one can say by doing this he has good chances to convince his readers.
